questions.text: Which is the most common type of ovarian tumor?
questions.solution:
Epithelial tumors are the most common type of ovarian tumors.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text: Which of the following is the most carcinogenic gene in ovarian cancer?
questions.solution:
BRCA 1 is the most carcinogenic gene in ovarian cancer.

5–10% of malignant ovarian tumors are genetic. BRCA 1 is associated with hereditary breast-ovarian cancer syndrome.

BRCA 1 is on chromosome 17q and BRCA 2 is on chromosome 13q.

MSH2 and MLH1 gene mutation is seen in hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). It is associated with malignancy of the colon, ovary, and endometrium.

questions.text: Which among the following reduces the risk of developing ovarian cancers?
questions.solution:
Bilateral tubectomy and hysterectomy reduce the risk of ovarian cancer.

Some ovarian malignancies originate in the fallopian tubes as dysplastic lesions which later spread to the ovary (dropping down theory). Thus, bilateral tubectomy reduces the risk of ovarian malignancy.

Risk factors for ovarian cancer:

  • Advancing age
  • Early menarche and late menopause
  • Talc exposure to the perineum
  • Family history of breast / ovarian cancer
  • Ovulation induction therapy by clomiphene citrate

Protective factors against ovarian cancer:

  • Use of oral contraceptive pills
  • Multiparity
  • Breastfeeding
  • Anovulation.

questions.text: Which among the following is the largest benign ovarian tumor?
questions.solution:
Mucinous cystadenoma is the largest benign ovarian tumor.

Mucinous cystadenoma is a mucoid-containing, thick-walled cyst. It is usually multilocular and lined by single columnar epithelium.

It is the third most common epithelial tumor of the ovary. It has a 10% chance of becoming malignant. About 40% of dermoid cysts are found in conjunction with mucinous cystadenomas.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding borderline ovarian tumors?

choices.text: Mitotic figures are < 4/10 high power field
Serous type is more common than mucinous type

questions.solution:
Stromal invasion is not seen in borderline ovarian tumors.

Borderline tumors of the ovary (also called tumors of low malignant potential) are a heterogeneous group of lesions defined histologically by atypical epithelial proliferation without stromal invasion.

The clinical progression of these tumors is distinct from ovarian carcinoma, so they are considered a distinct clinical entity.

Features of borderline ovarian tumors:

  • No stromal invasion
  • Mitotic figures <4/10 high power field
  • Survival rate is 90%
  • Usually occurs between 35-55 years of age 
  • Serous type is the most common, followed by mucinous type.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding ovarian cysts?

choices.text: Cobweb appearance is seen on USG in haemorrhagic cyst
Theca lutein cyst regresses with a fall in hCG levels
Leutoma of pregnancy is associated with multiple pregnancy
Follicular cyst is a benign epithelial tumor

questions.solution:
Follicular cyst is a physiological/functional cyst of the ovary. 

Physiological/functional cysts of the ovary:

  1. Follicular cyst - Failure of rupture of the follicle during ovulation.
  2. Theca lutein cyst - Stimulation of atretic follicles by abnormal HCG levels. It regresses when hCG levels fall.
  3. Luteoma of pregnancy - Due to prolonged elevation of hCG, like in multiple pregnancies.

Hemorrhagic ovarian cysts usually occur due to bleeding into the corpus luteum or other functional cysts at the time of ovulation. Hemorrhagic cysts are normal findings in ovulatory women, generally resolving within 8 weeks. 

Cobweb appearance on USG in a hemorrhagic cyst is shown below.

questions.text: Meigs' syndrome was suspected in a woman with right-sided pleural effusion, ascites, and an ovarian tumor. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Can be caused by ovarian fibroma
The tumor would be immobile with an irregular surface
Ascites and hydrothorax resolve after resection of the tumor
Pleural effusion is more common on the right side

questions.solution:
In Meig's syndrome, a benign ovarian mass is likely to be seen. Irregular surface and immobility are features of malignant tumors.

Meig’s syndrome is characterized by a triad of:

  1. Benign ovarian tumors
  2. Ascites
  3. Right-sided pleural effusion. 

The pleural effusions are usually right-sided, even though the left-sided and bilateral effusions are possible. 

Tumors causing Meigs' syndrome include ovarian fibroma, granulosa cell tumor, Brenner tumor, or thecoma. 

However, when the causative factor is ovarian secondaries, leiomyoma, and benign ovarian cysts (such as teratoma and mucinous cystadenoma), the condition is called Pseudo Meigs' syndrome.

Resolution of ascites and pleural effusion is seen after the removal of the tumor. 

Management:

  • Repeated paracentesis for ascites. 
  • Unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy in young patients for preserving fertility 
  • Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (TAH-BSO) in postmenopausal women.

Note: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) patients may also have a combination of ascites, pleural effusion, and elevated serum levels of CA-125. This is known as Tjalma syndrome or pseudo-pseudo Meigs’ syndrome.

questions.text: An elderly woman who was found to have an ovarian mass underwent staging laparotomy. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of Psammoma bodies. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Psammoma bodies are a histopathological finding of serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary.

They are calcified structures seen in areas of cellular degeneration. Their presence does not denote malignancy.

Psammoma bodies are seen in the following conditions:

  • Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Papillary serous carcinoma of the endometrium
  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary
  • Meningioma

The image below shows Psammoma body.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presented with complaints of dull pain over the right lower abdomen for the past 2  months. CT scan revealed a left-sided multiloculated adnexal mass and exploratory laparotomy showed small mucoid implants scattered in the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and findings point to a diagnosis of pseudomyxoma peritonei. It is associated with mucinous cystadenoma.

Pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) is a rare clinical entity characterized by diffuse intra-abdominal gelatinous and mucoid material on peritoneal surfaces. Spontaneous perforation of a mucinous cystadenoma leads to implantation of low-grade malignant tumor cells in the peritoneum.

However, the most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei is carcinoma of the appendix.

Diagnosis is by CT, MRI, and laparoscopy. Even after the removal of the ovarian tumor, these cells continue to secrete mucin. Recurrence rates are high.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman at 14 weeks of gestation was rushed to the ER with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. USG showed an edematous right ovary with a large cyst and disruption in adnexal flow on Doppler. Which of the following most commonly leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of ovarian torsion. Mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst) is the commonest tumor to undergo torsion, especially at the end of the 1st trimester or during puerperium.

Management includes derotation and cystectomy in pregnancy irrespective of gestational age. This is also done in non-pregnant women of reproductive age to preserve ovarian function. Resection is reserved for patients in whom malignancy is suspected.

Dermoid cyst is the most common germ cell tumor. It is also the most common benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group and in pregnancy. It is bilateral in 10-15% of cases. 

Dermoid cyst is derived from all three germ cell layers, but ectodermal derivatives are most common. Rokitansky’s protuberance is the most common site for the development of malignancy. It is seen as a projection covered by skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands, teeth, and bones. Sometimes thyroid tissue can be seen on histopathological examination, known as struma ovarii.

The image below shows a dermoid cyst with Rokitansky protuberance.

questions.text: Staging laparotomy was performed in a teenage girl who presented with an adnexal mass. Histopathological examination showed the following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows Schiller-Duval bodies. It is suggestive of a yolk sac tumor (endodermal sinus tumor).

It is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It occurs in ovaries or testes and sacrococcygeal areas in young children. It is usually unilateral. These tumors are usually associated with raised AFP and alpha 1 antitrypsin.

The image below depicts Schiller-Duval bodies. It consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells. 50% of yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic when present. 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: What is the counterpart of seminoma in females?
questions.solution:
The counterpart of seminoma in females is dysgerminoma. It is a germ cell tumor.

It usually arises in young women or in children. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor diagnosed during pregnancy. They account for approximately 1/3rd of all malignant ovarian germ cell tumors.

Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and the isoenzymes LDH-1 and LDH-2 may be used in monitoring individuals or disease recurrence.

Treatment involves unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.

Dysgerminoma was considered to be the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. Recent data indicates that in the past few decades, their incidence has reduced considerably. Immature teratomas are now the most common type of malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. 

The image below shows the histopathology of a dygerminoma, characterized by uniform cells resembling primordial germ cells separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytes.

questions.text: The most common ovarian tumor in women less than 20 years of age is _____.
questions.solution:
Germ cell tumors are the most common ovarian tumor in women aged less than 20 years.

Epithelial tumours are the commonest tumours. It accounts for 80% of all ovarian malignant tumours.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text: Which of the following tumors show raised CA-125 levels?
questions.solution:
Non-mucinous cystadenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the ovary. It has elevated CA- 125 levels.

CA-125 value > 35 U/ml is suggestive of epithelial ovarian cancer. 

Malignant conditions with raised CA 125 levels:

  • Ovarian epithelial carcinoma (most common cause)
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Pancreatic cancer
  • Colon cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Lung cancer
  • Lymphoma

Benign conditions with raised CA 125 levels:

  • Pregnancy
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Endometriosis
  • Uterine fibroid
  • Normally elevated in 1%  females
  • Acute peritonitis

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: A young woman with an adnexal mass is diagnosed with dysgerminoma. Which of the following tumor markers are likely to be elevated in her?
questions.solution:
Lactate dehydrogenase is the tumor marker in dysgerminoma.

Dysgerminomas are primitive neoplasms. They are the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement (15-20%).

It is seen in young women with an average incidence of 20 years of age. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumor diagnosed during pregnancy. They account for approximately 1/3rd of all malignant ovarian germ cell tumors.

It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (PALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG. Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and the isoenzymes LDH-1 and LDH-2 may be used in monitoring individuals or disease recurrence.

Treatment involves unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman is found to have an adnexal mass on evaluation. Above what risk of malignancy index (RMI) score is there a high risk of ovarian malignancy?
questions.solution:
Risk of malignancy index (RMI) score of 200 or more indicates a high risk for ovarian cancer in a patient with an adnexal mass. 

Risk of malignancy index (RMI) = U x M x CA125

  • U = Ultrasound score
    • The ultrasound result is scored 1 point for each of the following characteristics: multilocular cysts, solid areas, metastases, ascites, and bilateral lesions.
    • U = 0 (for an ultrasound score of 0)
    • U = 1 (for an ultrasound score of 1)
    • U = 3 (for an ultrasound score of 2–5).
  • M = Menopausal status
    • M= 1 (for pre-menopausal)
    • M= 3 (for post-menopausal)
  • CA-125 = Serum CA-125 level (in IU/ml)

For any post-menopausal woman with an ovarian cyst of size >1cm, RMI should be calculated.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Brenner tumor?

choices.text: It is associated with Meig's syndrome
Walthard cell rests and coffee bean nuclei are seen
It is not a malignant tumor

questions.solution:
Brenner tumors are usually benign but rarely they can turn malignant.

Brenner tumor (transitional cell tumor) is a benign, epithelial, unilateral tumor, resembling a fibroma. Histologically, Walthard cell rests and coffee bean nuclei are seen. 

Brenner tumor represent only 2-3% of all ovarian neoplasms, and <2% of these tumors are malignant. 

It is called Meigs' syndrome if the clinical picture is caused by an ovarian fibroma, granulosa cell tumor, Brenner tumor, or thecoma.

Meig’s syndrome is characterized by a triad of:

  1. Benign ovarian tumor
  2. Ascites
  3. Right-sided pleural effusion. 

Pseudo Meigs' syndrome is when the causative factor is ovarian secondaries, leiomyoma, and benign ovarian cysts such as teratoma and mucinous cystadenoma.

The image given below shows Walthard cell rest.

The image given below shows coffee bean nuclei.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presenting with 12 weeks of amenorrhea and passage of vesicles per vagina is suspected to have a molar pregnancy. On transvaginal ultrasonography, the left ovary appears as shown below. Which of the statements is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Regresses spontaneously after removal of molar pregnancy
It is seen with clomiphene administration
Oral contraceptive use is a risk factor

questions.solution:
The above scenario points to a diagnosis of theca lutein cysts in association with molar pregnancy. Theca lutein cysts are not associated with the use of oral contraceptives.

Lutein cysts types :

  1. Granulosa lutein cysts - They occur due to failure of regression of corpus luteum after 14 days of ovulation.
  2. Theca lutein cysts - They are found in association with hydatidiform moles, choriocarcinoma, and gonadotropin (hCG), or clomiphene therapy.

Theca lutein cysts occur due to the hyperstimulation of ovaries as a result of high hCG levels in molar pregnancies and other conditions. They are usually bilateral.

These cysts usually regress spontaneously in a period of 2-4 months following the evacuation of a molar pregnancy. 

Sometimes they can undergo torsion and cause marked pelvic pain. In such instances, laparoscopic untwisting of the cyst has to be done.

questions.text: A woman noticed premature breast development in her 7-year-old daughter and brought her to the gynecology OPD. USG revealed a right-sided adnexal mass. The patient underwent laparotomy and the biopsy revealed Call-Exner bodies. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Most common malignant tumor of ovary
Inhibin A is elevated more than inhibin B

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of granulosa cell tumor. It is associated with carcinoma endometrium. 

Granulosa cell tumors cells are estrogen-secreting ovarian tumors. It is seen in 80% of women over 40 years and 5% of pre-pubertal girls. Precocious puberty is seen due to excess secretion of estrogen.

It is a low-grade malignancy. It is almost always unilateral. Tumor marker inhibin B is frequently elevated more than inhibin A. Surgical resection is the treatment of choice.

On histopathology, it has characteristic Call-Exner bodies. It appears as a rosette arrangement of cells around an eosinophilic fluid space, as shown below.

questions.text: Which among the following high-risk patients are suitable for prophylactic oophorectomy?

choices.text: History of ovarian cancer in a 2nd-degree relative
Abnormal ovary in reproductive age group woman
One ovary removed for benign neoplasm

questions.solution:
Prophylactic oophorectomy is indicated if one ovary has already been removed for benign neoplasm.

Candidates suitable for prophylactic oophorectomy:

  • Nulliparous aged > 45 years
  • Any age with a history of ovarian, endometrial, or colon cancer in a 1st-degree relative
  • Grossly abnormal ovary in the premenopausal age group
  • One ovary removed for benign neoplasm
  • Previous history of breast carcinoma
  • Radiation-induced menopause

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presented with complaints of pelvic and abdominal pain, and significant weight loss. On CT scan, a bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and liver capsule involvement was seen. What stage does this belong to?
questions.solution:
Stage 3 ovarian cancer is a unilateral or bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and/or regional lymph node involvement and liver capsule involvement.

Grading of ovarian cancer:

  • Grade 1 - well-differentiated cancers have cells that closely resemble normal cells and are less likely to spread or recur.
  • Grade 2 - moderately differentiated cancer cells. 
  • Grade 3 - poorly differentiated cancers show increasing abnormality of appearance compared to normal cells. They are also more likely to spread and recur. 

Related Pearl: Staging of Ovarian cancer

  • Stage I:
    • A: Tumor confined to unilateral ovary
    • B: Bilateral ovary
    • C: Capsule rupture
      • C1: Surgical  spill
      • C2: pre-operative capsule rupture
      • C3: malignant ascites
  • Stage II:
    • A: Extension to fallopian tubes/ uterus.
    • B: Extension to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissues
  • Stage III:
    • A1:Positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes(para-aortic)
    • A2:microscopic extrapelvic peritoneal deposits
    • B: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits <2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.  
    • C: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits >2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.
  • Stage 4:
    • A: Malignant pleural effusion
    • B: Extra-abdominal spread/Inguinal lymph node involvement

questions.text: A 26-year-old nulliparous woman is diagnosed with early-stage ovarian cancer. Which surgery should be done in her case?
questions.solution:
Unilateral oophorectomy is preferred in a young woman who has not completed her family in case of early-stage disease.

Related Pearl: Management in Ovarian Malignancy

questions.text: Which of the following ovarian tumors is the most radiosensitive?
questions.solution: Dysgerminoma is the most radiosensitive ovarian tumor. They are highly susceptible to radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old post-menopausal woman on HRT presented with abdominal pain for the past 6 months. On examination, a non-tender, right adnexal mass was palpable. USG showed a 3 x 3 cm smooth ovarian cyst. What is the next best step in her case?

choices.text: Reassure and advise regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirmation of USG findings by CT scan
Exploratory laparotomy for evaluation of cyst
CA- 125 level estimation; if normal, advise regular follow-up

questions.solution:
CA-125 level measurement is the next best step according to the latest RCOG guidelines for post-menopausal ovarian cysts.

Management includes the following:

  • Calculation of Risk of Malignancy Index (RMI) = U x  M  x  Ca-125, where
    • U = ultrasound score
    • M = menopausal status
    • Ca 125 = serum levels
  • Laparotomy/laparoscopy only indicated if size >5 cm or RMI >200.

Option B - CT scan is not recommended for initial evaluation. It is done only for further evaluation and when RMI > 200.

questions.text: Examination of a resected specimen of an ovarian mass reveals signet ring cells are seen as shown below. Which of the following conditions is this associated with?
questions.solution:
Signet ring cells are seen in Krukenberg tumor.

A Krukenberg tumor is an ovarian malignancy that metastasized from a primary site, most commonly from the stomach (70%). Carcinomas of the colon, appendix, and breast (mainly invasive lobular carcinoma) are the next most common primary sites.

The route of spread may be:

  • Lymphatic
  • Hematogenous
  • Transcoelomic

They are usually bilateral and have a smooth surface with a waxy consistency. They retain the shape of a normal ovary.

Given below are the images of the Krukenberg tumor's gross appearance and histological appearance with signet ring cells:
